entry.title: May Garden/Growing Update: Radishes, Blueberries, Tillandsia, Succulents, & Etc.
entry.content:
Garden stuff has been progressing without me writing much about it because recently I am lucky if I can manage to wake up early enough or stay up long enough at home to water anything, much less take photos of it and muse upon its growth. Suffice to say that at the start of spring I went crazy over some on-sale seeds and attempted to plant some in seed starter pots.

march pots

Dragon's Tongue Wax Beans in particular looked super cool and exciting and got off to a great start indoors…

lil things

…but when I transplanted them outside, they didn't last two weeks. Maybe I didn't harden them off enough? Maybe, like swiss chard, they're too delicate to withstand transplanting? When I transplanted them I also planted some new beans, and these happen to be doing really well. Unlike the indoor starts, they have very deep green leaves and thick stems.

transplants in the back, new beans in the front

My other surprise is the success of my radishes, which I planted outdoors in March alongside some arugula and swiss chard. Look, they're doing it! They're really growing!

radishes

They're probably the most attractive-looking edible thing I've grown this far, especially since the spinach and swiss chard I started growing before last winter tasted pretty mediocre. My mistake was not staggering out their sowing, however, so I pretty much just have this batch and that's it for now.

Speaking of the spinach, as soon as the heat started getting up to around 70 degrees Fahrenheit, they started sending up flowers. The plants rise up over my knee now, and their stalks are as thick as my fingers, and it's hard to believe that they used to be just little seeds.

biiig spinaches

My lime tree has really perked up now that the weather has gotten better, though has still suffered from leaves that are pale green and strangely droopy and bendy. They feel almost elastic. Some internet research has uncovered that I, in my passion to not drown it, I may be under watering it. Since being given a couple thorough soaks, the leaves indeed seem a little stiffer and greener. I've also repotted it into something larger and more sturdy than its initial black pot. No flowers or fruit yet, probably because it's been stressed and dehydrated for the better part of its life with me.



Speaking of stressed and dehydrated, before the winter started Andou and I received a very impressive-looking 30 year old jade tree...

jade tree on the sunniest part of our house, the laundry room

I was very concerned about killing it, especially since, despite my diligent watering, its leaves began to fall off in gooey yellow curls. Some internet research has uncovered that I, in my passion to not kill it, I was probably over watering it. I've since then toned down and the tree seems okay on its new perch over the dryer. One branch even bloomed little white blossoms! Whoa!

My air plants from last year are doing well. In the picture below, the top plant had one pup that is now fairly large, and the bottom actually had two pups, so it's getting to be a handful.

spot the pups!

It's been about a year since I got them at the UW Street Fair, and when the fair rolled around again this weekend I was excited to pick up more! Four more, in fact. I was excited to get ones with weirder tentacle shapes, and then also picked up two teensy blooming ones, one of which already looks like it's growing a pup. The two little ones are already a year old and were blooming already, so it makes me a little bewildered about why my plants from last year are not blooming. Maybe I should invest in some fertilizer.

spot the pup!

Speaking of plants retrieved at fairs, my sedums are doing okay. The iceplant-looking one is faring the best of all of them. I've moved three of them to a little pot I bought at Daiso and tried to give them succulent soil to see if they would do any better than in normal potting soil, but thus far I don't observe any difference.

sedums in a long pot

Speaking of succulent soil, the reason why I had some is because I got another succulent! I saw it on sale at the hardware store and couldn't resist. Donkey/burro tail plants are so neat-looking. Some of the little bean-leaves had detached and fallen between into the dirt inside the pot, so I took them out and placed them in their own pots to see if they might grow into new plants.

burro tail on the dryer

And that's (almost) all of what I have growing.

entry.title: Garden Update: October
entry.content:
I have to admit that I was really pessimistic about those seeds, but they have been growing well! I even found someone growing seedlings in eggshells and decided to try this out too, leaving out some swiss chard seeds in potting mix on the back steps and covering them with some plastic to emulate the humidity that I hear encourages plants to sprout. And they are sprouting!

little things~

Unfortunately I wasn't very scientific about my observations, so I don't know if they sprouted faster than the chard planted straight into the ground. Oh well.

The "ground chard" is doing fine, by the way, though looking at this picture now I realize that the weeds around it are doing splendidly too.

gotta pull those, i guess

Also, the mystery plant that was sprouting last time has finally taken on a distinct shape and revealed itself to be spinach (I think)!

kinda looks like spinach, right?

Which means the other plant is definitely carrot.

yeah...definitely

The last thing we planted out back is cilantro, and it's actually starting to look like cilantro!

whoa!

Now that the growing process was actually a success, I'm a little worried about how they'll fare now autumn and its cool shroud has finally crept near. A coworker assures me that swiss chard is hardy as anything and that a friend of his had swiss chard faring crispily beneath even the snows of Snowpacalypse last year. For what it's worth, I've been assembling high-tech cloches to shelter what plants I can from the chill and occasional hail that has precipitated recently.

do yo thing, my pretties

As for the front yard, that agastache is blooming, though there are no hummingbirds in sight. Maybe next year.

you are so hard to take a picture of

Herb alley is okay...

and fragrant as ever

And some of my sedums were, unfortunately, starting to look not-that-great, so I transplanted them into a ridiculously large planter where I hope they'll have more room to grow. When I was moving them around I was a dismayed to see the Miracle Gro potting soil was densely packed and damp around the plants that had never grown that strongly (in particular, the plant second from the right and last on the left). So, no more Miracle Gro I guess. This potting soil is from Carpinito Brothers and the sedums seem okay.

shrug

 Last but not least, my air plants, whose pups are growing well if slowly. Actually, I was surprised to see that the stricta (pictured left) started developing a second pup off to the side!

you go, girl

Comments

nadine a.
Oooh, I would be very interested in this photo-heavy kitty blog...also, is that the epiphyte from that one conference? I was so jealous to hear they were handing those out! I hope it comes back home soon D:
Kathleen Tuite
Your photos in this post are lovely and they blended in seamlessly with the Flickr blog posts that are also in my feed (as well as a photo-heavy blog about fostering kittens). I have a tiny epiphite like in the last photo there... except it has mysteriously disappeared from GRAIL! Oh no!

entry.title: Things Sprouting & Acidic Soil
entry.content:
it's alive!

Those seedlings we planted are finally sprouting!

Unfortunately, other than the swiss chard (which has such a distinctive red stem), I'm not sure what the others are, since we forgot to label them.

i think it's cilantro on the left, and carrot on the right? maybe spinach?

I also prepared for transplanting the huckleberry plant into the ground by first checking out some online resources and the acidity of the pot that it was in with a pH tester.


sweet acid bro

Since the pot soil was pretty acidic, I tried to amend some of the garden soil with peat moss to keep it that way. Blueberry plant also got some peat moss to keep it healthy, since the pH tester registered a perfect neutral for the soil that it was in.

I also discovered a lime tree on sale at the grocery store, and placed it to live near the indoor herbs currently hanging out on the dryer. The herbs are a thai basil and a stevia, both gifted to me from a "free" bin at the farmer's market. I'm not really sure what I'll do with either of them yet, particularly since I think the thai basil is about to flower and die soon.

indoor homies

The stevia is getting pretty tall so I may try and cut it back as suggested, though my inner novice worries that an entire plant might just go belly up after being nipped.

entry.title: Vermicompost!
entry.content:
Ever since Leilani told me about them, I've been absolutely obsessed with doing vermicompost, aka getting a box, filling it with worms, and leaving my organic materials in there to rot and be eaten and transformed into ~*castings*~ after about six months.

Step 1: Get the box. In this case, two Rubbermaid boxes into which were easily drilled rows and columns of holes. The holey one is meant for the worms; the one without the holes is meant to gather what I believe some people refer to as "worm tea."

break out that drill

Step 2: Get and prepare the bedding  Actually, I got the worms first before preparing the bedding  which consisted of an issue of Real Change and some pages from The Stranger (torn haphazardly into one-inch, stripper-ad-covered strips), and a bunch of old peanut shells and bok choy ends from that night's dinner. Because worms thrive in a wet environment, you're supposed to soak the papers until they feel like a damp sponge.

worms and bedding

Step 3: Once the beddings are prepared, put in the worms! We got these worms from Stoneway Hardware, which seemed to be one of the few places in Seattle that have them in supply. At first glance the canister seemed full of dirt, but after curiously (and then furiously) drumming out the clump of soil from the bottom of the canister, we stared in shock and not a little abrupt nausea at the wriggly, thrashing mass.

worms!

They thrashed away from the light, some of them so vehemently that they fell down the drill holes and had to be rescued and placed back amidst the feast. We then covered the tub with a thin layer of compost (having heard that compost can be full of helpful microbes) and placed it lovingly inside an empty cabinet for easy disposal of plant-based debris.

It's hard to say what really attracted me to vermicompost, but I guess it's the idea that you're closing the circle -- putting some of your food to the creatures who will help you convert it into stuff to help more plant foods grow. I guess it doesn't hurt that I really enjoy taking care of things in general, especially when "taking care of things" consists of placing a bok choy end in a cabinet every now and then.

thar be worms

entry.title: Autumn Perennial Planting
entry.content:
This past week has been busy with moving, the start of my new job, and the start of autumn quarter, but at some point we finally found time to plant the starters that we (well, I) bought (starry-eyed) at various nurseries.

I've spent the past couple weeks reading books to raise my gardening level a little higher before attempting The Real Thing. Library discoveries include Talking Dirt by Annie Spiegelman, and Decoding Gardening Advice: The Science Behind the 100 Most Common Recommendations, by Jeff Gillman and Meleah Maynard. Both are incredibly readable and filled with great beginner information, especially for someone like me, who scarce knew the difference compost and mulch. Yes, they are different! And they do different things! Whoa! Both books are also incredibly forgiving and advise constant questioning of advice and continued experimentation and learning. So...here we go!

Now knowing that "compost" is something which can be added to the dirt of places to make it all-around better for plant growth, we purchased some large bags and amended the beds around the back of the house, which (though covered appealing rich brown mulch) proved to be mostly rocky, pale dirt. Thereafter we planted some packets of seeds that seem to be ready to plant at about this time: overwintering carrots, swiss chard, spinach, cilantro. I am wary of seeds, especially since we just planted them straight in rather than growing them indoors beneath a light or something first, but I guess we'll see what happens with these.


dat compost

We also transplanted that blueberry bush, which had -- since the time I bought it -- started exhibiting an alarming amount of yellowing leaves, as well as leaves that curled at their edges and became a pale brick-red color that was soft to the touch. Maybe scorch? Maybe a fungus? Maybe a canker? Maybe the effect of general nutrients or acidity leaking from its black gallon pot? In any case, we transplanted it into a corner of the beds with some scoops of azalea/rhododendron fertilizer to make up for any acidity the soil may not have, since I was a bad gardener and haven't checked the pH yet...I was too nervous of leaving it to wilt further in that container.

sorry, blueberry plant :(

It's had some new young leaves since this last photo, which hopefully grew not just because of the burst of nitrogen in the fertilizer, which apparently can cause new growth that then just dies in winter because it isn't strong enough to withstand the cold. (Which is why fertilizers should be applied in spring, I suppose. Then again, another part of one of these books says it's best to plant perennials in autumn, when hot weather isn't there to stress them into not forming good roots...ahh!)

One thing learned from these books is that, when buying perennials, it's better to choose a small, unblooming candidate. Small plants are better able to withstand transplanting, and if they don't yet have blooms, they can focus more of their energy on growing strong roots. It's also important to make sure that plants aren't root-bound, which can be checked by tipping the plant out of its pot and making sure the roots are white, not encircling the pot, and not smelly.

Anyway, one of the new starters we got was a lemon balm.

lovely smelly smell

Lemonbalm is part of the mint family, and is fragrant as all hell. You only need to touch the stems or leaves to have your hands come away with an inexplicably lemony and lovely aroma. It's apparently quite easy to take care of (even to the point of growing flush with more pruning?). For now it's by the front door so that we can grope it every time we leave.

Beside it is a rosemary because of course.

like duh

They're hardy enough that they grow on sidewalks here, tempting passersby to take a sprig despite the likelihood of such a sidewalk denizen having been anointed with pesticides or (worse) dog pee. In any case, rosemary always struck me as an uncomplaining garden occupant with the advantage of yielding omelette-friendly seasoning.

Beside that is a stout chocolate mint, which some years ago I had tried to grow on a windowsill, to no avail. These seem a bit more sturdy than my previous twig of a chocolate mint, so here's hoping the mint family is as vigorous as people complain about, and can withstand my less-than-masterful attempts to support its survival.

good luck, little one

The last plant we planted in was an agatasche, or "hummingbird mint," which can possibly attract hummingbirds, if they indeed exist here.

i think i saw one here once?

In general it was an attractive enough plant that I decided to forego my want of only edible gardening plants to obtain it. Presently it's planted in the bed around the monkey-tail tree, which makes me a little nervous since one of the things these books said was, Don't raise a garden around the trunk of the tree! This can apparently smother the roots there, and can lead to a greater chance of diseases or fungi attacking the tree. I believe that this garden was placed around the tree to make the house look pretty before we moved in, but Andou doesn't think that it's large enough to really harm the tree. I hope so, because the tree is so large and beautiful that it would be a shame if it died...

So, yeah, anyway, to be honest I didn't really check the rootbounded-ness of any of these perennials, nor am I entirely sure, having already planted them, whether they were overly-rootbound or not...but as of this morning they were still alive, so, that's good.

While digging up the front beds to place in new plants, we ended up unearthing some mysterious bulbs which look a lot like garlic but may not be. Planted here by previous tenants perhaps? Some of them were sadly crushed, but I'll re-plant them once the earth cools down a little and I'm ready to plant some tulips I received as a gift.

we'll see what occurs later
